Expectation1: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation1: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: As a priest, the anticipation for the most significant religious holiday of the year fills me with both pride and pressure. The congregation expects me to lead the prayers, deliver a moving sermon, and be present for every ritual. The church will be packed, and my absence would be unthinkable. Yet, as a citizen, I know the community center is hosting a free vaccine clinic this weekend, and volunteers are desperately needed. The city has also sent reminders about tax documents, and I promised myself I’d get them sorted early this year. I feel the weight of both roles pressing in—my parishioners need spiritual guidance, but my neighbors need practical help. I can’t ignore the call to serve in the clinic, especially when public health is at stake. My mind races, torn between the sacred duties of my faith and the civic responsibilities I hold dear. The expectations from both sides are clear, but I am caught in the middle, heart pounding, unsure which path to take.
